[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/server/src/error.rs] [Enum: Error] [Information disclosure] Can malicious peers craft requests that trigger verbose error messages in InvalidRequest(String) variant, leaking internal system state, peer information, or validator configuration details to attackers? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/server/src/error.rs] [Enum: Error::InvalidRequest] [Input validation bypass] Does the InvalidRequest variant properly sanitize error message strings, or can attackers inject control characters, escape sequences, or format strings that corrupt logs or bypass security monitoring? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/server/src/error.rs] [Enum: Error::StorageErrorEncountered] [Storage attack vector] Can malicious peers trigger storage errors repeatedly to cause excessive disk I/O, database contention, or resource exhaustion affecting validator node performance and consensus participation? (High)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/server/src/error.rs] [Enum: Error::UnexpectedErrorEncountered] [Error masking] Does wrapping all network errors as UnexpectedErrorEncountered hide critical security events like authentication failures, rate limiting violations, or malicious peer detection from security monitoring systems? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/server/src/error.rs] [Enum: Error] [Serialization attack] Are there any unsafe serialization patterns in the Serialize/Deserialize derives that could allow malicious peers to craft error payloads causing panics, memory corruption, or denial of service when deserialized? (High)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/server/src/error.rs] [Enum: Error] [Type confusion] Can attackers exploit the PartialEq and Eq implementations to create error values that incorrectly compare as equal, bypassing error-based access controls or rate limiting mechanisms? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/server/src/error.rs] [Enum: Error::InvalidRequest] [Error amplification] Can malicious peers send requests with extremely long invalid parameters that get stored in InvalidRequest(String), causing memory exhaustion or string allocation attacks when error messages propagate through the system? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/server/src/error.rs] [Enum: Error::StorageErrorEncountered] [Database state leakage] Does StorageErrorEncountered expose internal database error messages that reveal schema information, query patterns, or state machine details useful for planning attacks against the storage layer? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/server/src/error.rs] [Enum: Error] [Clone implementation] Does the Clone derive create expensive deep copies of error strings, allowing attackers to trigger excessive memory allocation and copying operations through repeated error triggering? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/server/src/error.rs] [Enum: Error] [Error persistence] Are error instances persisted, logged, or stored in any way that allows malicious peers to inject crafted error messages into persistent storage, potentially corrupting audit trails or historical data? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/server/src/error.rs] [Function: get_label()] [Metric manipulation] Can attackers trigger specific error types to manipulate metrics and monitoring dashboards, hiding real attacks by flooding counters with benign error labels like 'invalid_request'? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/server/src/error.rs] [Function: get_label()] [Label collision] Is there any risk that the static string labels ('invalid_request', 'storage_error', 'unexpected_error') could collide with labels from other subsystems, causing metric confusion or incorrect alerting? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/server/src/error.rs] [Function: get_label()] [Pattern matching exhaustiveness] If new error variants are added to the Error enum, will the get_label() match statement cause compilation failures, or could unhandled variants lead to runtime panics or undefined behavior? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/server/src/error.rs] [Function: get_label()] [Lifetime issues] Does returning &'static str prevent any dynamic error labeling or context injection, potentially limiting security logging capabilities and making incident response more difficult? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/server/src/error.rs] [Function: get_label()] [Metrics gaming] Can malicious peers deliberately trigger 'invalid_request' errors to pollute metrics and hide their malicious activity among noise, bypassing anomaly detection systems? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/server/src/error.rs] [Function: get_label()] [Case sensitivity] Are the lowercase labels ('invalid_request', 'storage_error', 'unexpected_error') case-insensitive when used in metrics systems, or could case variations bypass monitoring rules? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/server/src/error.rs] [Function: get_label()] [Label injection] Could the static label strings be misinterpreted by downstream logging or metrics systems if they contain special characters or are used in string interpolation contexts? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/server/src/error.rs] [Function: get_label()] [Observability blind spots] Does mapping multiple detailed error causes to simple labels lose critical security context needed for incident response and attack attribution? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/server/src/error.rs] [Function: From<aptos_network::application::error::Error>] [Error conversion loss] Does converting network errors to UnexpectedErrorEncountered with to_string() lose critical security context like peer identity, attack type, or authentication failure details? (High)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/server/src/error.rs] [Function: From<aptos_network::application::error::Error>] [Network attack masking] Can attackers exploit the fact that all network errors are treated as 'unexpected', preventing proper differentiation between benign network issues and active attacks like connection flooding or protocol violations? (High)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/server/src/error.rs] [Function: From<aptos_network::application::error::Error>] [to_string() attack] Does calling to_string() on network errors trigger expensive formatting or allocation operations that could be exploited for denial of service through repeated error generation? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/server/src/error.rs] [Function: From<aptos_network::application::error::Error>] [Error chain break] Does the From implementation break error chains or lose stack traces that would be useful for debugging security incidents and identifying attack patterns? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/server/src/error.rs] [Function: From<aptos_network::application::error::Error>] [Nested error explosion] If network errors contain large amounts of context or nested error chains, could the to_string() conversion create unbounded string allocations causing memory exhaustion? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/server/src/error.rs] [Function: From<aptos_network::application::error::Error>] [Authentication failure hiding] Are authentication and authorization failures from the network layer properly distinguished, or are they generically wrapped as UnexpectedErrorEncountered, preventing proper security event correlation? (High)

[File: aptos-core/peer-monitoring-service/server/src/error.rs] [Function: From<aptos_network::application::error::Error>] [Panic propagation] Could network errors that should panic (like invariant violations) be caught and converted to UnexpectedErrorEncountered, hiding critical bugs or security vulnerabilities?
